member.summary: A keyboard and mouse event simulator which posts events to a simulation provider (libuiohook by default).

member.name: P:SharpHook.EventSimulator.TextSimulationDelayOnX11
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.
member.value: The delay between simulating individual characters when simulating text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support simulating arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this property is ignored.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateKeyPress(SharpHook.Native.KeyCode)
member.param: The code of the key to press.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateKeyRelease(SharpHook.Native.KeyCode)
member.param: The code of the key to release.

member.name: M:SharpHook.EventSimulator.SimulateTextEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g. emojis) is supported.
On Windows text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed - longer delays add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can also be used to get the currently configured delay - the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.param: The wheel rotation. A positive value indicates that the wheel will be rotated up or left, and a negative value indicates that the wheel will be rotated down or right.
The scroll type (considered only on macOS).

remarks.para: On Windows the value 120 represents the default wheel step. As such, multiples of 120 can be used, but it's not required. The value of is ignored.
On macOS it's recommended to use values between -10 and 10. This will result in quite a small scroll amount with pixel scrolling, so is recommended for line scrolling instead of pixel scrolling.
On Linux there is no fixed recommendation, but multiples of 100 can be used. The value of is ignored.

member.name: T:SharpHook.Logging.LogEntry
member.summary: Represents a log entry from libuiohook.

remarks.para: For simple handling the and properties are anough. For more advanced handling you can use the entries' formats and arguments.

Each log entry from libuiohook has the following format:
function [line]: message

The function and line reference the source code of libuiohook itself, and can be retrieved using the and properties. The message can be retrieved by splitting the text by : and getting the trimmed second part.
You shouldn't create instances yourself. Instead, use the class to create them in the logging callback.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Native.UioHook.PostText(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates the input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g. emojis) is supported.
On Windows text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed - longer dealys add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can be used to get the currently configured delay - the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Native.UioHook.GetPostTextDelayX11
member.summary: Gets the delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.
member.returns: The delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support posting arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this method always returns 0.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Native.UioHook.SetPostTextDelayX11(System.UInt64)
member.summary: Sets the delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.
member.param: The delay (in nanoseconds) between posting individual characters when posting text on Linux.

remarks.para: X11 doesn't support posting arbitrary Unicode characters directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this method does nothing.

Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation.
The default delay is 50 milliseconds.
On Windows and macOS this method always returns 0.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Providers.UioHookProvider.PostText(System.String)
member.summary: Simulates input of arbitrary Unicode characters.

remarks.para: The text to simulate doesn't depend on the current keyboard layout. The full range of UTF-16 (including surrogate pairs, e.g. emojis) is supported.
On Windows text simulation should work correctly and consistently.
On macOS applications are not required to process text simulation, but most of them should handle it correctly.

X11 doesn't support text simulation directly. Instead, for each character, an unused key code is remapped to that character, and then key press/release is simulated. Since the receiving application must react to the remapping, and may not do so instantaneously, a delay is needed for accurate simulation. This means that text simulation on Linux works slowly and is not guaranteed to be correct. can be used to increase (or decrease) the delay if needed - longer delays add consistency but may be more jarring to end users. can be used to get the currently configured delay - the default is 50 milliseconds.

member.name: T:SharpHook.TaskPoolGlobalHook
member.summary: Represents a task pool-based implementation of .

remarks.para: The event handlers will run with the specified parallelism level on separate threads inside the default thread pool for tasks. This way the hook itself will not be blocked if the handlers are long-running. The exception is the event which will run on the same thread that called the method since at that point it doesn't matter anymore that the hook is not blocked.
Setting inside the handlers will have no effect as they are run on other threads.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Testing.TestProvider.Run
member.summary: Runs the testing hook if is set to . Otherwise, does nothing.

remarks.para: This method simply blocks the current thread until is called. Actual event dispatching happens directly in the method. As such, it's different from the real global hook where the thread which calls the method is the thread which dispatches events - this is not the case with .
This method can be called when the provider is already running - it will also block the current thread. Calling the method will unblock all blocked threads.

member.name: M:SharpHook.Testing.TestProvider.RunAsync
member.summary: Runs the testing hook if is set to . Otherwise, does nothing.

remarks.para: This method doesn't do anything and returns a which will be finished when is called. Actual event dispatching happens directly in the method. As such, it's different from the real global hook where the thread which calls the method is the thread which dispatches events - this is not the case with .
This method can be called when the provider is already running - the same will be returned.
